items.headline: Sensorion raised €60M backed by €20M from Sanofi to advance gene therapies for hearing loss
items.preview: Sensorion has secured €60 million, including a strategic investment from Sanofi, to enhance its gene therapy programs.
items.article:
French biotech company Sensorion announced today a €60 million (about $72 million) reserved offering including a €20 million strategic investment from Sanofi. The remaining €40 million was subscribed by existing shareholders and new investors.

The Montpellier-based biotech said its cash runway has been extended to the first half of 2027. The new funding will support the advancement of its genetic programs, including SENS-601 and SENS-501, targeting genetic forms of hearing loss. Specific milestones include regulatory approval for Clinical Trial Applications and first patient enrollment for SENS-601.

Why this matters: This funding positions Sensorion to focus on advancing its lead gene therapy programs through critical regulatory and clinical milestones, potentially bringing transformative treatments for genetic hearing loss closer to patients.

items.headline: Roche: strong growth in all world regions and a full pipeline in late stage
items.preview: Roche reported a 7% increase in sales and a robust late-stage pipeline, indicating strong growth.
items.article:
Roche increased sales by 7% at constant exchange rates to CHF 61.5bn and lifted core operating profit by 13%. This growth was driven by blockbusters in the Pharma division, with revenues climbing by 9%.

Roche's performance was resilient across regions, with notable growth in China despite pricing reforms. The company also reported a strong late-stage pipeline, with ten drug candidates entering Phase III development in 2025.

Why this matters: Roche's impressive financial results and robust pipeline position it well for future growth, reflecting its commitment to innovation and operational excellence.

items.headline: Timing of Cord Blood Transplant Affects Graft Disease
items.preview: Research reveals that circadian rhythms influence the success of cord blood transplantation.
items.article:
Researchers have uncovered a crucial link between circadian rhythms and the success of cord blood transplantation (CBT), highlighting how the timing of procedures can influence the risk of acute graft-versus-host disease (aGVHD).

The study found that higher levels of soluble CD26 at certain times can suppress T cell activity that causes aGVHD, suggesting optimal timing for transplantations. This insight could lead to personalized transplant protocols that align with patients' biological rhythms.

Why this matters: Understanding the impact of circadian biology on transplantation could significantly improve patient outcomes and reduce complications associated with aGVHD.

items.headline: Obesity catalysts in 2026
items.preview: The obesity treatment landscape is evolving with new GLP-1 therapies and upcoming Phase III data.
items.article:
The obesity race is widening, with the launch of oral GLP-1 agonists by Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk expected to challenge existing treatments. Novo recently launched oral Wegovy, while Lilly anticipates FDA approval for orforglipron.

2026 is set to bring multiple Phase III catalysts and proof-of-concept readouts, indicating a dynamic shift in obesity treatment options.

Why this matters: The introduction of new mechanisms and players in the obesity treatment space could enhance patient outcomes and provide more effective options for managing obesity.

items.headline: Tenpoint wins FDA nod for combination presbyopia eye drop
items.preview: Tenpoint Therapeutics received FDA approval for Yuvezzi, a new eye drop for presbyopia.
items.article:
The FDA approved Yuvezzi, an eye drop developed by Tenpoint Therapeutics for presbyopia. The company raised $235 million in funding to support the launch, expected in the second quarter of 2026.

Yuvezzi combines two compounds to improve focus and reduce redness associated with presbyopia. It showed effectiveness in Phase 3 trials, outperforming its individual components.

Why this matters: The approval of Yuvezzi represents a significant advancement in the treatment of presbyopia, potentially benefiting millions who suffer from this age-related condition.
